review.title: Adams Conditioning and Likelihood Ratio Transfer Mediated Inference
review.abstract: Forensic science advocates the use of inference mechanisms which may be viewed as simple multi-agent protocols. An important protocol of this kind involves an agent FE (forensic expert) who communicates to a second agent TOF (trier of fact) first its value of a certain likelihood ratio with respect to its own belief state which is supposed to be captured by a probability function on FE's proposition space. Subsequently FE communicates its recently acquired confirmation that a certain evidence proposition is true. The inference part of this sort of reasoning, here referred to as likelihood ratio transfer mediated reasoning, involves TOF's revision of its own belief state, and in particular an evaluation of the resulting belief in the hypothesis proposition.
histories: In this revision, besides the improvement of several details, some remarks and results concerning transposition of the conditional and the prosecutor's fallacy have been included. Moreover, the order sensitivity of processing of likelihoods from a likelihood pair has been illustrated. An additional acknowledgement is included. (Extension from 43 to 50 pages)

In this revision, besides the improvement of several details, an embarrassing miscalculation with implications in several Sections has been detected and (hopefully) repaired. A description of the Taxi Color Case (TCC) has been included. A transition system of credal states is proposed as a standard model of proposition and belief kinetics. (Extension from 50 to 57 pages)

sections.heading: 7 Potential implications for forensic logic
sections.text: In this section, I intend to examine what effects the results obtained in the preceding sections might have on forensic logic. It is plausible that subjective probability has remained within the realm of forensic reasoning, assuming these two questions: (i) how close the form of subjective probability theory ultimately applied in forensics will be to the views originally expressed by de Finetti and Lindley, and (ii) to the extent to which other perspectives of probability will ultimately be housed in a coherent picture. I have assumed from the outset (but without proof) that some form of controlled coexistence of different paradigms of probabilities represents a promising path to the future.

sections.text: These views are not specific to forensics and can be generalized to an arbitrary environment in which LRTMR can be useful. sections.heading: 7.2 Frequentist versus subjectivist duality
sections.text: There is no reason to expect or wish that one of these two views (or any of the intermediate views that have been developed so far) would emerge, on the basis of philosophical reflection alone, as the victorious perspective on the concept of probability, leaving only a highly acclaimed role in the history of science. This position has a direct impact on some discussions in forensic science. I consider any argument based on the alleged superiority of one of these views to be flawed. Flawed arguments can lead to valid conclusions, but this phenomenon seems to be applicable in some of the current debate about the foundations of forensic logic.

sections.heading: 7.5 Meta-axioms for the design of semantic models for a probability calculus based reasoning framework
sections.text: The limitation to homogeneous semantic models can be understood as a possible meta-axiom of semantic modeling: The homogeneity axiom (on semantic models of LRTMR-style argumentation patterns) requires all actors to be able to apply the same conceptual (logical mathematical) modeling of their beliefs. To develop the theory, it is plausible to assume semantic homogeneity to the point at which it is demonstrably untenable or clearly unattractive (if this point is reached at all). There are other meta-axioms that can be assumed: The time stamp axiom states that when agents report beliefs or quantities based on beliefs (such as probabilities), such reporting must be true to the current beliefs of the agents at the time of reporting. A third useful meta-axiom is the instantaneous revision that states that the partial information must be based on the principle that the receipt of the following meta cognitive statement must be consistent with the principle of their receipt of the following.

sections.heading: 8.3 Conclusions III: concerning likelihood ratio transfer versus likelihood pair transfer
sections.text: The following conclusions can be drawn with respect to the advantages and disadvantages of transferring probability ratios compared to the simultaneous or asynchronous transmission of probability pairs. • Adams conditioning with single probability provides an appropriate response for TOF when it receives an update of a single probability. • If MOE sends a probability ratio LR (E, H, ¬ H) to TOF, it provides enough information for TOF to revise its beliefs, with or without conditioning the evidence. • TOF can split a probability ratio r, which it receives in an arbitrary manner, into a fraction r = l / l ² and revise its persuasion function either with respect to both probabilities (in any case using a single probability of Adams conditioning).

metadata.abstractText: Forensic science advocates the use of inference mechanisms which may be viewed as simple multi-agent protocols. An important protocol of this kind involves an agent FE (forensic expert) who communicates to a second agent TOF (trier of fact) first its value of a certain likelihood ratio with respect to its own belief state which is supposed to be captured by a probability function on FE’s proposition space. Subsequently FE communicates its recently acquired confirmation that a certain evidence proposition is true. The inference part of this sort of reasoning, here referred to as likelihood ratio transfer mediated reasoning, involves TOF’s revision of its own belief state, and in particular an evaluation of the resulting belief in the hypothesis proposition. Different realizations of likelihood ratio transfer mediated reasoning are distinguished: if the evidence hypothesis is included in the prior proposition space of TOF then a comparison is made between understanding the TOF side of a belief revision step as a composition of two successive steps of single likelihood Adams conditioning followed by a Bayes conditioning step, and as a single step of double likelihood Adams conditioning followed by Bayes conditioning; if, however the evidence hypothesis is initially outside the proposition space of TOF an application of proposition kinetics for the introduction of the evidence proposition precedes Bayesian conditioning, which is followed by Jeffrey conditioning on the hypothesis proposition.
